noun.description: A porous device for removing impurities or solid particles from a liquid or gas passed through it.
An arrangement whereby vehicles may turn left (or right) while other traffic waiting to go straight ahead or turn right (or left) is stopped by a red light.

verb.description: Pass (a liquid, gas, light, or sound) through a device to remove unwanted material.
examples: the patient is hooked up to a dialysis machine twice a week to filter out the cholesterol in the blood

verb.description: Move slowly or in small quantities or numbers through something or in a specified direction.
examples: people filtered out of the concert during the last set
the news began to filter in from the hospital

phrases: I have no filter and I do say things that I probably shouldn't say
origin: Late Middle English (denoting a piece of felt): from French filtre, from medieval Latin filtrum felt used as a filter, of West Germanic origin and related to felt.
